definitions.definition: the energy from the sun, a lamp, etc. that makes it possible to see things
definitions.sensetop: by the light of somethinginto the lighttowards the light

definitions.definition: an expression in somebody’s eyes that shows what they are thinking or feeling

examples.text: There was a soft light in her eyes as she looked at him.

definitions.definition: light colours in a picture, which contrast with darker ones

examples.text: Examine the artist's use of light and shade.
contrasting areas of light and dark

definitions.definition: a match or device with which you can light a cigarette

examples.text: Have you got a light?
Do you have a light?
Could you give me a light?

definitions.definition: a window or an opening to allow light in

examples.text: leaded lights

definitions.definition: according to the standards that somebody sets for himself or herself

examples.text: The police were left to do the job according to their lights.

definitions.definition: to be between somebody and a source of light

examples.text: Could you move—you're in my light.

definitions.definition: to go to sleep very quickly

examples.text: She returned to bed and went out like a light.

definitions.definition: to be pleasant, friendly and polite

examples.text: I can’t complain—he’s been all sweetness and light with me.
People think she's all sweetness and light, but she actually has a temper.

definitions.definition: to be fun and easy to deal with

examples.text: It’s not all sweetness and light being an actor.

definitions.definition: the excitement of city life

examples.text: Although he grew up in the country, he's always had a taste for the bright lights.

definitions.definition: to make new information known to people

examples.text: These facts have only just been brought to light.

definitions.definition: to make a problem, etc. easier to understand

examples.text: Recent research has thrown new light on the causes of the disease.

definitions.definition: to become known to people

examples.text: New evidence has recently come to light.

definitions.definition: to not let people know that you are good at something
when you have had time to think calmly about something; in the morning when things are clearer

examples.text: These things always look different in the cold light of day.

definitions.definition: if you see something or put something in a good, bad, etc. light, it seems good, bad, etc.

examples.text: You must not view what happened in a negative light.
They want to present their policies in the best possible light.

definitions.definition: after considering something

examples.text: He rewrote the book in the light of further research.

definitions.definition: to fail to stop at a red traffic light
something that shows you are nearly at the end of a long and difficult time or situation

examples.text: For the first time since the start of his treatment, we can now see light at the end of the tunnel.

definitions.definition: somebody suddenly understood or began to understand something

examples.text: I puzzled over the problem for ages before the light suddenly dawned.

definitions.definition: the person somebody loves more than any other
used to describe somebody who is stupid, not thinking clearly or not paying attention
to finally understand or accept something, especially something obvious

examples.text: He thinks she’s wonderful but he’ll soon see the light! *(= realize that she’s not)*

definitions.definition: to begin to believe in a religion
to begin to exist or to become publicly known about

examples.text: He's written a lot of good material that has never seen the light of day.
Some of her paintings never even saw the light of day.

definitions.definition: to make something start burning

examples.text: A spark from the fire had set light to a rug.

wordOrigin: noun ,Old English lēoht, līht (noun and adjective), līhtan (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch licht and German Licht, from an Indo-European root shared by Greek leukos ‘white’ and Latin lux ‘light’.
